subject: RE: [junit] Some questions about JUnit 4
msgSnippet: ... I was disappointed by this news as well.  I do use an IDE for most of the day, but when I have to work remotely I use vi over SSH and a GUI TestRunner on
messageBody:
On Mon, 2005-08-22 at 09:50 +0100, Clarke, Andrew wrote:
> Was I the only person to be saddened by this announcement? Maybe I'm
> just being sentimental here but the Graphical TestRunner's green
> bar/red
> bar was one of the earliest delights of Junit.
>
> Besides, as a casual user of Java I have yet to find the energy to
> learn
> an IDE. When I do have to code Java I generally use my normal text
> editor and the graphical test runner, which I find is quicker and
> easier
> to use than the text version.
>
> I know Kent has an evangelising streak - automated unit testing,
> xp/agile, etc - which he has used well in the service of the software
> community but I think insisting on the use of an IDE is a crusade too
> far.

I was disappointed by this news as well. I do use an IDE for most of
the day, but when I have to work remotely I use 'vi' over SSH and a GUI
TestRunner on my local machine. So personally, I would like to have at
least one graphical TestRunner. (Yes, I know that I could set up many
IDEs to do the same thing -- Eclipse for instance -- but that chews up
too many resources on my laptop.)

Kent, perhaps you would consider adding a community section to CVS and
allow us to add code there. You can document this portion of the
repository as being "unwarranted" (whatever that would mean). It would
allow for the community to add their $0.02. I don't think anyone wants
to make more work for you or Erich, but it would be nice to have an easy
way for everyone to use JUnit in a way that is comfortable to them.

--
Jason Rogers
